name: emc-custom-codes
title: Extended Codes CodeSystem
description: Set of codes identified as being needed but not found in existing Code Systems

concept.definition: Unique identifier provided or a universal ID, if used in the country
Auto-generated unique identification if used by the implementation

concept.display: Child's Identity unknown/prefer to remain anonymous
concept.definition: The client's identity is unknown or the client's prefers to remain anonymous
Client's first name
Client's middle name
Client's family name or last name
The date and time of the client's visit
The client's time of birth (if <1 day old)

The client and/or Caregiver does not know the date of birth of the client (this is to check whether the age and date of birth are facts or estimations)

concept.display: Breastfed how many times in 24 hours?
concept.definition: Number of times the client is breastfed in 24 hours
Based on the number of feeds during a 24 hour period the result is auto-calculated to determine sufficient feeds
Based on the number of feeds during 24 hour period the result is auto-calculated to determine insufficient feeds

concept.display: Young Infant receives other food or fluids
concept.definition: The client is receiving other food or drinks besides breastmilk

concept.display: What milk is being given as a replacement feed?
concept.definition: The health care worker discusses the milk being given to the client as a replacement feed and determines if it is appropriate replacement milk

concept.display: How many replacement feeds during the day and night (24 hours)?
concept.definition: How often the client is receiving replacement feeds during the day and night (24 hours)
Based on the number of feeds during the day and night (24 hours) the result is auto-calculated to determine sufficient replacement feeds
Based on the number of feeds during the day and night (24 hours) the result is auto-calculated to determine insufficient replacement feeds

concept.definition: Does the care giver give the client any breastmilk at all?

concept.display: Unable to perform test - assumes vomits everything/unable to drink
concept.definition: The health care worker is unable to perform test on the client therefore the health care worker should assume the client vomits everything or is unable to drink

concept.display: Skin Pinch Goes back Very slowly (More than 2 seconds)
concept.definition: The client's skin goes back very slowly after skin pinch of abdomen (More than 2 seconds)

concept.display: Skin Pinch Goes back Slowly (2 seconds or fewer, but not immediately)
concept.definition: The client's skin goes back slowly after skin pinch of abdomen (2 seconds or fewer, but not immediately)
The client's skin goes back normally after skin pinch of abdomen (immediately)

concept.display: Molluscum Contagiosum - Skin coloured pearly white papules with central umbilication. Most commonly seen on face and trunk in children.
concept.definition: The client has Molluscum Contagiosum - Skin coloured pearly white papules with central umbilication. Most commonly seen on face and trunk in children.

concept.display: Warts - Papules or nodules with a rough (Verrucous) surface
concept.definition: The client has Warts - Papules or nodules with a rough (Verrucous) surface

concept.display: Seborrhea - Greasy scales and redness on central face and body folds
concept.definition: The client has Seborrhea - Greasy scales and redness on central face and body folds

concept.display: Fixed Drug Reactions - Generalised red, wide spread with small bumps or blisters; or one or more dark skin areas
concept.definition: The client has Fixed Drug Reactions - Generalised red, wide spread with small bumps or blisters; or one or more dark skin areas

concept.display: Eczema - Wet oozing sores or excoriated, thick patches
concept.definition: The client has Eczema - Wet oozing sores or excoriated, thick patches

concept.display: Steven Johnson Syndrome - Severe reaction due to cotrimoxazole or NVP involving the skin as well as the eyes and the mouth.  Might cause difficulty in breathing
concept.definition: The client has Steven Johnson Syndrome - Severe reaction due to cotrimoxazole or NVP involving the skin as well as the eyes and the mouth.  Might cause difficulty in breathing

The client has had pus draining from the ear for 14 days or more

concept.display: Possible Serious Abscess - Hot Tender Swelling
concept.definition: The client has a possible serious abscess - Hot tender swelling
The client has Cellulitis - Red tender skin

concept.display: Papular Itching Rash(Prurigo) - Itching rash with small papules and scratch marks. Dark spots with pale centre
concept.definition: The client has Papular Itching Rash(Prurigo) - itching rash with small papules and scratch marks. Dark spots with pale centre

concept.display: Ringworm (Tinea) - An itchy circular lesion with a raised edge and fine scaly area in the centre with loss of hair.  May also be found on body or web on feet
concept.definition: The client has Ringworm (Tinea) - An itchy circular lesion with a raised edge and fine scaly area in the centre with loss of hair.  May also be found on body or web on feet

concept.display: Scabies - Rash and excoriations on torso; burrows in web space and wrists, face spared
concept.definition: The client has Scabies - Rash and excoriations on torso; burrows in web space and wrists, face spared

concept.display: Chickenpox - Vesicles over body.  Vesicles appear progressively over days and form scabs after they rupture
concept.definition: The client has Chickenpox - Vesicles over body.  Vesicles appear progressively over days and form scabs after they rupture

concept.display: Herpes Zoster -  Vesicles in one area on one side of body with intense pain or scars plus shooting pain.  Uncommon in children except where they are immuno-compromised (e.g. if infected with HIV)
concept.definition: The client has Herpes Zoster -  Vesicles in one area on one side of body with intense pain or scars plus shooting pain.  Uncommon in children except where they are immuno-compromised (e.g. if infected with HIV)
